content.title: Primordial Black Holes and the Planck Mass
content.summary: Primordial black holes (PBHs) are hypothetical black holes that could have formed in the early universe. Those with initial mass near the Planck mass would have already evaporated via Hawking radiation, while more massive PBHs may still exist today and could constitute dark matter.

concept.formation: PBHs form from density fluctuations in the early universe, not from stellar collapse
concept.mass_range: Could range from Planck mass to many solar masses
concept.current_status: Not yet detected, but actively searched for

examples.interpretation: Planck mass black holes evaporate in ~10⁴ Planck times
PBHs of this mass would be evaporating now

critical_mass.significance: PBHs with M > M_crit at formation still exist

mass_windows.status: Allowed, could be all dark matter

minimum_black_hole_mass.description: Smallest meaningful black hole has M ~ m_P
minimum_black_hole_mass.reason: Schwarzschild radius equals Compton wavelength at M = m_P
minimum_black_hole_mass.quantum_effects: Lighter 'black holes' would be dominated by quantum effects

final_evaporation.description: All black holes eventually shrink to Planck mass
final_evaporation.physics: Final evaporation burst probes quantum gravity
final_evaporation.energy_release: E = m_P c² ≈ 10⁹ J ≈ small nuclear weapon

dark_matter_hypothesis.appeal: PBHs are 'natural' dark matter - no new particles needed
dark_matter_hypothesis.challenges: Formation mechanism requires fine-tuned primordial fluctuations
dark_matter_hypothesis.current_status: Can constitute some, but not all, dark matter in most mass ranges

primary_sources.author: Carr et al.
primary_sources.title: Primordial Black Hole Constraints for Extended Mass Functions
